abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Education Project for Bhutan
            had the following ratings: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project. The eleven schools built under Second Education
            Project (SEP) are attractive structures which will serve as
            relatively high quality schools for years to come as
            Bhutan's rapid development continues. SEP-financed
            schools lack a sufficient number of books to stock new
            libraries. The outcome of implementation of the civil works
            activities under SEP demonstrate the importance of carrying
            out advance preparatory tasks, including site surveys, the
            development of designs and drawings, the simplification of
            bidding documents, and capacity building at the local level.
            A key impediment to the effective use of new teaching
            approaches for improved classroom management and to
            stimulate children's learning can be largely attributed
            to a lack of familiarity with them. Lessons learned from the
            vast literature on the importance of good school leadership
            for instituting pedagogic reforms and effective management
            of schools are in evidence in Bhutan. More effective
            hand-over between component managers during staffing
            re-alignments was required.
